title: 112_hr4238
content: The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 may also be referred to as the TBI Act of 2012. This Act reauthorizes the Traumatic Brain Injury Act. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012, also known as the TBI Act of 2012, amends the Public Health Service Act to focus on preventing, recognizing, and responding to traumatic brain injuries. It updates the program to address these issues and extends the timeline to 2020. The National program for traumatic brain injury surveillance and registries is amended under the Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 to extend the timeline for reporting to Congress on federal agency collaboration. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 is amended to collect and disseminate epidemiological studies on traumatic brain injury in military personnel, standardize clinical definitions, and conduct a study in consultation with federal agencies within the Department of Health and Human Services. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 authorizes various federal agencies to conduct studies and appropriates necessary funds for the purpose. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 authorizes federal agencies to conduct studies and appropriate funds for fiscal years 2013 through 2017. Amendments are made to Section 1252 of the Act regarding state grants for traumatic brain injury projects, including the inclusion of private entities on advisory boards. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 authorizes federal agencies to administer funds for individuals with disabilities under various Federal laws. Coordination of activities with other agencies is required to ensure effective implementation. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 mandates the establishment of a national plan for activities related to brain injury, in consultation with stakeholders and agencies. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2012 requires the creation of a national plan for brain injury activities, involving collaboration with various agencies. The plan must be periodically reviewed and revised, with reports made available to the public. Changes include updating the timeframe from 2001-2005 to 2012-2017 and specifying the distribution of grants for fiscal years 2013 and beyond. The Secretary will award grants under this section to qualifying applicants in amounts of at least $100,000 in the initial fiscal years and at least $250,000 in subsequent years. The Secretary will award grants to qualifying applicants based on population size, with larger populations receiving proportionately greater amounts. Amendments are made to State grants for protection and advocacy services under Section 1253 of the Act. Amendments are made to the annual reporting requirements under subsection (h) and (i) to create a uniform format for reports. Subsection (k) is also amended. Amendments are made to the annual reporting requirements under subsection (h) and (i) to create a uniform format for reports. Additionally, each protection and advocacy system shall have access to medical centers of the Department of Veterans Affairs and other related treatment facilities to provide services. Amendments are made to the annual reporting requirements under subsections (h) and (i) to create a uniform format for reports. Each protection and advocacy system shall have access to medical centers of the Department of Veterans Affairs and other related treatment facilities to provide services, including referrals, discharge planning, monitoring, and investigation of conditions and treatment. Subsection (l) is updated to reflect the years 2013 and 2014 through 2017, while subsection (m) is amended to reference the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000. Amendments are made to the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000, specifically regarding an interagency program for trauma research. Subsection 1261 of the Act is amended to update certain subparagraphs and provisions. Amendments to the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 include the addition of subparagraph (E) for studies on children and youth with traumatic brain injury and updating the year in subsection (i) to 2017.
